comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: While there are at least two people called "Archduke Eugen", I believe this one is Archduke Eugen Ferdinand Pius Bernhard Felix Maria of Austria-Teschen, a member of the Habsburg dynasty who was "Archduke of Austria and a Prince of Hungary and Bohemia."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Blor, www.genealogyimagesofhistory.com/images/patchwork.JPG seems to confirm your identification. I can just read Commander in Chief of the Austrian Army And www.gutenberg-e.org/steuer/archive/detail/C05.p21B.Archdu... is another picture of him. And here's one in the same uniform, probably as Hoch- und Deutschmeister des Deutschen Ritterordens or grandmaster of the Teutonic Order": www.austro-hungarian-army.co.uk/biog/erzeugen.htm

comment.author: 63860770@N07
comment._content: Thanks bior and swanq for his full name and titles. We'll add the info to our records.

comment.author: 30817808@N00
comment._content: Archduke Eugene of Austria (1863-1954) Austrian or Austro-Hungarian commander on the Balkan and Italian Fronts during World War I.

comment.author: 7313591@N02
comment._content: If the photograph dates from c. 1910, it can’t be the same man (he would be fifty...)

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Bain quite often rephotographed older photos when they needed a portrait and didn't have anything current. I think there is a thumbtack visible at top right, which indicates that this is a photo of an earlier print. ro.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arhiducele_Eugen_de_Austria has a picture dated 1888 that has him looking younger than this. He became Grand Master of the Teutonic Knights in 1894. I wonder whether this might have been an official photo taken when he became Grand Master, when he would have been about 31.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: New York Times Current History; The European War, Vol 2, No. 4, July, 1915 April-September, 1915 archive.org/details/newyorktimescurr26377gut has another picture of the Archduke that must have been taken years before the NYT published it in mid-1915. There was clearly a shortage of recent portraits of him in the U.S. when he was a significant figure in WWI. [Note: It's a little difficult to find the picture in the EPUB reader I have as a browser plugin, but if you can find the heading "Britain’s Cabinet and Munitions" just page back a bit. The HTML version at www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/26377 may be more convenient.]
